newsitem.title: GERMANY: Euro row in Kohl coalition deepens with new threat.
newsitem.headline: Euro row in Kohl coalition deepens with new threat.

text.p: A rift within Chancellor Helmut Kohl's ruling alliance over Europe's planned single currency widened on Saturday when one of his partners openly raised the prospect of leaving the coalition.
The row pits members of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) against its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union (CSU), and above all Bavarian premier Edmund Stoiber.

"If the stability criteria are not adhered to and the euro becomes a soft currency, the CSU will have to draw the necessary conclusions," Markus Soeder, a CSU leadership member, told the Bild am Sonntag weekly in an article to be published on Sunday.
Stoiber has demanded that the budget deficit limit of three percent of gross domestic product (GDP) for single currency membership be stricly interpreted as 3.0.

Soeder, the head of the CSU's youth wing, said if the criteria were softened, the party could then take a decision which would mean "get out of the coalition in Bonn and dissolve our joint parliamentray group with the CDU".

With France saying it will not meet the 3.0 goal and economists predicting Germany will also struggle, senior CDU officials have indicated a looser intepretation would be better than postponing the project, due to start on January 1, 1999.
